case.name: Nokia Corporation v Cellular Line Australia Pty Ltd (No 2) [2006] FCA 980 (11 August 2006)

costs
costs of cross-respondents on hearing of application for orders under the trade practices act 1974
misleading conduct in relation to a lease
cross-claim by respondents-owners of shopping centre against their agents
cross-claimants seeking indemnity against agents should the applicant's claims succeed
applicant's claims dismissed and accordingly cross-claim dismissed

federal court of australia act 1976 (cth), s.43
supreme court rules (vic), o.16, r.5
federal court rules , o.5, r.6(1), o.5, r.12

the constitution (63 & 64 vict c 12), s.76(ii). the applicant sued the respondent shopping centre owners for misleading conduct inducing her to enter into a lease contract. the respondents cross-claimed for rent and damages for breach of contract and also claimed indemnity from the cross-respondents as their leasing agents who were alleged by the applicant to have engaged in the misleading conduct. the respondents successfully defended the action, succeeding also on their cross-claim, and, accordingly, the cross-claim against the cross-respondents was also rejected. rather than an order against the applicant (a person of no substance) the cross-respondents sought costs against the respon

dents who, they claimed, should in turn rely upon a right of indemnity against the applicant. the applicant argued as a preliminary point that the court had no jurisdiction to hear the cross-claim on the basis that the indemnity sought against the cross-respondents was not part of the matter between the applicant and the respondents which attracted the court's jurisdiction. at the hearing of the application, the court (jenkinson j) reviewed its power to order the applicant to pay to the cross-respondents their costs, finding that the federal court rules are more restricted than those of other jurisdictions and are unclear on whether or not cross-respondents are parties to "the proceeding" between the original parties. the court concluded that if the term "proceedings" in the federal court rules contemplated all actions under one serial number, s.43 of the federal court of australia act 1976 (the act) permits an order against any party to pay another's costs.

citances.sentence: 3 In Nokia Corporation v Cellular Line Australia Pty Ltd (No 2) [2006] FCA 980 , delivered on 11 August 2006, the Court ordered that 60% of the applicant's costs be paid by the first and second respondents, 20% be paid by the third respondent, and 20% be paid by the fourth respondent (less 20% of costs referable to the applicant's costs of preparing evidence of sales of counterfeit products after 24 February 2006).
